operator theory

Let A(D)A\p{\D}A(D) be the C\CC-vector space of all holomorphic functions on D\DD and suppose that L ⁣:A(D)→C\func{L}{A\p{\D}}{\C}L:A(D)→C is a multiplicative linear functional, that is,

L(af+bg)=aL(f)+bL(g)andL(fg)=L(f)L(g)L\p{af + bg} = aL\p{f} + bL\p{g} \quad\text{and}\quad L\p{fg} = L\p{f}L\p{g}L(af+bg)=aL(f)+bL(g)andL(fg)=L(f)L(g)

for all a,b∈Ca, b \in \Ca,b∈C and all f,g∈A(D)f, g \in A\p{\D}f,g∈A(D). If LLL is not identically zero, show that there is z0∈Dz_0 \in \Dz0​∈D so that L(f)=f(z0)L\p{f} = f\p{z_0}L(f)=f(z0​) for all f∈A(D)f \in A\p{\D}f∈A(D).
Solution.

Set z0=L(z)z_0 = L\p{z}z0​=L(z). Since LLL is not identically zero, there exists f∈A(D)f \in A\p{\D}f∈A(D) such that L(f)≠0L\p{f} \neq 0L(f)=0. Thus, by multiplicity of LLL, we have L(f⋅1)=L(f)L(1)  ⟹  L(1)=1L\p{f \cdot 1} = L\p{f}L\p{1} \implies L\p{1} = 1L(f⋅1)=L(f)L(1)⟹L(1)=1. Similarly, L(zn)=(L(z))n=z0nL\p{z^n} = \p{L\p{z}}^n = z_0^nL(zn)=(L(z))n=z0n​, and so by linearity of LLL, we have shown that the claim is true whenever fff is a polynomial.

Now let f∈A(D)f \in A\p{\D}f∈A(D). Since fff is holomorphic, we may apply the factor theorem to get f(z)−f(z0)=(z−z0)g(z)f\p{z} - f\p{z_0} = \p{z - z_0}g\p{z}f(z)−f(z0​)=(z−z0​)g(z). By multiplicity of LLL, L(f(z)−f(z0))=L(z−z0)L(g(z))=0L\p{f\p{z} - f\p{z_0}} = L\p{z - z_0}L\p{g\p{z}} = 0L(f(z)−f(z0​))=L(z−z0​)L(g(z))=0. By linearity, we conclude that

L(f(z))=L(f(z0))=f(z0)L(1)=f(z0).L\p{f\p{z}} = L\p{f\p{z_0}} = f\p{z_0}L\p{1} = f\p{z_0}.L(f(z))=L(f(z0​))=f(z0​)L(1)=f(z0​).

To complete the proof, we need to show that z0∈Dz_0 \in \Dz0​∈D. If this were not the case, then f(z)=1z−z0∈A(D)f\p{z} = \frac{1}{z - z_0} \in A\p{\D}f(z)=z−z0​1​∈A(D), which implies that L(f(z))=f(z0)=∞∈CL\p{f\p{z}} = f\p{z_0} = \infty \in \CL(f(z))=f(z0​)=∞∈C, but this is absurd.
